text:
Alright, now let’s hand it
to Jia-Ren
Ok, thank you Mark.
So let me introduce myself first.
My name is Jia-Ren.
And I joined the AWS

Premium Support
Taipei Team

I also started as a
Cloud Support Engineer,

Then I gradually transferred from
handling the profiles in Database
to Big Data.
In 2019 I had the opportunity to

become an Ops Manager,
just like Tim.

And now I am handling the
profiles in Big Data Analytics,
Before I joined the AWS
PS Team in Taipei,

I also worked in a few
major companies in Taiwan.
So maybe when we are
at the Q&A session later,
I can share something with you

because some people probably want
to know about the environment and
culture in AWS Support.
As I have worked in these
rather well-known companies,

the information I share with you
may be a good reference.
It’s what I feel about

the differences between a foreign
company and a local company.

So there are also
three QR Codes here, so

if you want now,
you can scan them and see

if there is any position that
matches your expertise.

You can also keep an eye on
our Amazon Job.
It is updated regularly
with new position vacancies.
Ok.

Ok, now
at this session, we mainly
want to talk about our
Leadership Principles.

So before you go to a job
interview, you’ll definitely look
for what other people are saying,
and read about their experiences.
In fact, not just AWS,

every company has this
kind of behavior guidelines to
follow during interviews.
I am going to talk about
which of the leadership principles

are valued by
AWS Premium Support, and
some of the interview tips.
Then you can use these tips
in your job applications, and

not just for AWS Support jobs,
but also for other roles in AWS,
or even for other companies.

I believe you can apply the
same interview skills.

Ok, you must all
know about our Leadership

Principles, and that there are
14 of them, but you’ve probably
read the news update recently.
We have a news update.

It says that we’ve added two more
Leadership Principles, but
they are not included here today.

I will briefly talk about
one of them later.
Now these are the

original 14
Leadership Principles.
Do not think of them
as something that we

see very often
in schools, like some sort of

slogans hanging on the walls.
We don’t actually need them,

or we only memorize them
when we are taking an exam.
After working here for a while,

I have a real understanding of
AWS Amazon.

We actually practice
this kind of culture
entirely in our daily work.
Whether it’s hiring,

meeting,
or working on a project with
colleagues to solve issues,
we are constantly demonstrating
these Leadership Principles.

So they are not just slogans
hung on the walls.
They are something we actually use
to verify if what we do every day
is in line with
these Leadership Principles.

You must have read it in the
news reports or magazines or

in the biography of
our founder Bezos,
that we are striving to be

the Earth's most
customer-centric company.

So among these 14
Leadership Principles,
you can probably figure out
which ones are the most important.

Certainly the first one:
Customer Obsession.
So for Customer Obsession,
what do we want to find out?
We want to know that in your past
work or internship experience, or

even when you worked as a team
back in school days, did you ever
help your users or
your customers think about
what their experience was like,
did you think about providing them
with more than they could imagine,

rather than just meeting
their basic needs.
So for Customer Obsession,
when you are at an interview,
you can think about the relevant
past experience that you have,

and demonstrate them
at the interview.

Or you can talk about whether
you’ve tried to collect

user or customer
feedback.
We say “user” mainly because

not everyone would
have internship experience or
client-facing experience.
In many scenarios, you can

consider your classmates that
you worked with for a presentation,

or the users of the system
or feature that you developed
during your internship
as part of your customers.

These scenarios can be
used for this purpose.
How did you develop a feature that
you find excellent for the clients?

And how you added something more,
like good UI or
user-friendly interfaces.
These are great examples that
you can use during an interview.
So after Ownership,
another important one is
Learn and Be Curious.

Just as Mark and Tim both have
mentioned, there are way
more things than we can learn here.

One of the main reasons for my role
change is that I think there is

always something new here.
There are always new technologies,
and the latest services.
There are more than we can learn.
Colleagues are from everywhere.
Everyone has different specialties.

We can learn many different
things from the colleagues.
So “Learn and Be Curious”

is also very important for
Cloud Support Engineers.

For example, I am just
specialized in database, but

when I am solving a client’s
issue about networking,

I can’t just say I will relay this
one to a coworker in networking.
Like Mark, help me with networking.

Instead we want
the engineer to think

that it is a networking issue,
so I can take this chance to learn
about networking knowledge.
Like how do I receive packets, and
how to analyze received packets?

So in this way,
you will gain more skills, and your

skills will also be more diverse,
and get better and better.
So “Learn and Be Curious”

is also a very
important Leadership Principle
for us.

And on the right-hand side,
Earn Trust is also
something we value very much.
Mostly because we want to know

whether you are able to
respect other people’s opinions.
If other people’s opinion is
different from yours,
can you offer some data and
some explanations to convince them
to let them know you are correct?
So that you can bring the team or
the project down on the right path.

So you can also think about
whether you have similar examples

from your past work experience
or school time, and then

you can demonstrate them
during your interview.

And the next important one is
Dive Deep.

It is a Leadership Principle
just as important as

Learn and Be Curious for
Cloud Support Engineers.
We want to know
how you analyze an issue,

and if you have the right
direction for troubleshooting,
instead of shooting in the dark.

Like, l’ll try this command first.
If it’s not good, I’ll try another.
Instead, you must have logic,
knowing how to deal with the issue.
Like I’ll recreate the issue first.
If impossible, I’ll look at the log.
What are the clues in the log?
Step by step,

can you dig further
into the root cause, and give
the client a satisfying solution.

So Dive Deep is
also very important.
It is a very important

Leadership Principle for our
Cloud Support Engineers.

And the last one is
Deliver Results.
As the name suggests,
“Deliver Results” refers to

whether you can deliver good
results in everything you do.
Can you overcome all difficulties?
If you want to complete a project,
you need to discuss the demand.
Maybe it’s hard to clarify the demand,
maybe the user is not specific,
maybe you need to communicate and
coordinate with different teams.
These are all examples of how

you can demonstrate whether you
are able to Deliver Results.

So these Leadership Principles
that I just mentioned are
the ones that we value a lot

in the role of
Cloud Support Engineers.
But it doesn’t mean you only
need to prepare for these ones.

Each of them is equally
important to us.

I think the best way to prepare for
an interview is that, first of all,
you can write down
the most memorable experiences

that you have in projects,
in operations, and in teamwork.
You write them all down.

You specify the details,
and the things you have done.

And then apply the STAR
technique in interviews,
which we will talk about,

to demonstrate the skills
to the interviewers.

Actually,
in any kind of interviews,
we don’t really mind if you
try to guess if we will

test you on Customer Obsession
during the interview.

The interviewers don’t
really like to ask those trick

questions that have with a twist,
or that are hard to understand.
For the questions that we ask,
you’ll quickly realize that:
oh I think he probably wants to
find out if I have certain skills,

and so I’d better look at the
examples I prepared and see if I
have a certain example that works.

For instance, I developed a
feature, and the client loved it.

That happens to be a great example
to demonstrate a certain

special skill that the interviewers
wish to find out about.
So these are some of the techniques
you can prepare for an interview.

And so these
Leadership Principles
are actually not very complicated.
There is no complicated concept.

You can get
what we are trying

to say literally from the
words themselves.
I mentioned earlier that

we have an additional new
Leadership Principle,

which is that
we strive to be

the Best Employer On Earth,
like around the world.
For this purpose,
we actually provide each new hire
with comprehensive education training.
And everyone also knows that
the pandemic has changed our life.
The work mode has evolved as well.
So we also offer the remote option.
We want to keep both productivity
and flexibility for everyone, so
you can ask your supervisor to
adjust based on your development.
If you just join the company,
actually when you just start a job,
in an entirely new environment,

you will certainly
feel very lonely.

There is nobody to talk to.
Nobody is there to

work hard and learn things
together with you.
So at this stage,
we suggest that you

can come to the office to
chat and hang out with colleagues.

After a while when you are familiar
enough with your job,
then maybe we can begin
with the hybrid work mode.
You work from home a few days,

and work in office a few days,
something like that.

So based on the needs
of your current development, you

can discuss with your supervisor
the options of your work location.

So we provide in-office,
remote, and hybrid

work modes for
everyone to choose from.

In addition to these,
our work environment is

actually very open when
you still work in office.
Discussions between colleagues
are very open and welcome.
We exchange techniques.

We are happy to share what we
know with everyone.

So the interaction and
the workplace atmosphere
are very good.
When you leave your desk, nobody
asks why you are gone for so long,

and where you have been.
You wouldn’t have that feeling.

So the entire work environment
is very pleasant to me.

Especially for someone coming from
my previous work environment,

I really like this
entire working atmosphere, and

how colleagues work together here.
It’s really good.
So this is all I want to say
about Leadership Principles.

You can prepare for
your interview

based on the points
I just mentioned.
So let’s turn to the next slide.
Wait a second.

Ok, next one is
some interview tips.
And for the interview tips,

the first one is
have a complete resume.
I would recommend having
a resume in English,
as it is a foreign company.

And in the resume,
you don’t need to write a lot.
Be concise and to the point.
You need to let us think as soon as

we see the resume: your skills
match our criteria, and you are
what we are looking for.

So you don’t actually need to
write long essays about yourself.
Just highlight project experiences.

Such as what you did
in those projects.
It’d be good if you can show numbers.
Like if a feature that you created
brought a 20% increase in revenue.
This would be powerful proof.
They speak more to the

interviewers than just talking about
all the issues you handled

when you were developing
certain features.

It’ll give us a stronger feeling that
you have this kind of ability, and
that you have this kind of results.
So I suggest that you spend more
efforts on your resume to make

it faster for the interviewers
to identify the
important points in the resume.

Then they can ask questions
corresponding to your
specialties and characteristics.
And you can also show
your strengths better.
And the next one is that
I think it is something that you

must do no matter which position
you are applying for.
You must first know this job, and
this company’s business model.
What services do they provide?
Have they been covered recently
in any news or magazines?
What is their development status?
When you are interviewing for AWS,
of course we don’t expect you
to understand what these 200+
services are all about.
But we have some core services,
such as EC2, S3, EBS,
that are very very basic, and
that are used most frequently.

Almost every client and every user
that uses AWS

will definitely launch EC2.
They will definitely do that.
So I think you need to have

at least some basic understanding
of the use of these basic elements.
You can learn more about them via
some nice channels, like Facebook,
or some of the Boot Camps

we organize.
You are welcome to participate.

Even on our YouTube channel,
you can learn something

about AWS. There are
videos to give you a crash course
on certain services in a few mins.

I suggest that you can check
them out before the interview.

And you express your ideas,
and discuss them with

the interviewers
at the last Q&A session.
So this is definitely something you
can prepare before the interview.
In addition,
the interview is bi-directional.

Don’t think that it’d just be the
interviewers asking you questions.
I also suggest that you
can prepare several questions.
But personally,
I don’t suggest that you ask about
what the company will do next, or
what the vision is for the future.
We’d prefer that you ask about
our daily life,

and what it’s like to work
in this role.
How do we handle or

address issues when
they happen?

What resources do we
provide for you?

These questions can let
the interviewers understand that
you are interested in this job and
you want to know about these things.
Rather than asking about our next

step, our future products,
or our new services,

it’s better to demonstrate
your interest in this position.
So it’s like this.

So you can prepare all these
questions that you want to ask.

During the interview, there are
usually 10-15 minutes in the end
for you to have some other
interactions with the interviewers.
You can ask questions at this time.
And lastly, I personally
think it is very important.
This is also probably what people
would suggest when you try to look
for any info on the Internet.

It’s that you have to apply the
STAR technique during the interview
to answer any question.

So I will quickly talk about
what STAR is.
The first one is Situation.

You need to describe the situation
that you face clearly.
Don’t oversimplify it.
For example, maybe you’d say,
a user reported to me that
his SQL query is slow.
That’s all.

But if you can elaborate on
the Situation, saying

a client reported a
Situation to me, that
his SQL query is very slow.

This query is very important
to the business. For example,

this Situation caused a 20%
decrease in our shipment.

You can describe this
kind of personal experience.
So you know that

if you add more specific
description to the Situation,

you will make the
interviewers feel like they were
right there with you at that moment.

They’d know that the situation
was actually very urgent.
You back it up with enough details.
But don’t make it a long essay.
You don’t need to tell the

interviewers every single
relevant and irrelevant detail.

Instead you should talk about
the important points concisely.
If the information is not enough,

the interviewers will usually try
to further ask more questions
to find out more about
the things they are interested in.

So people always wonder,
oh, does it mean

the scenario has to be related
to a skill, or related to
cloud services?
Actually no.
When you were a student,
or an intern, or at work,
you had many
interactions with other people.

They can be used as case
examples for the interviewers
to know something about you.
Take Dive Deep for example.

When people see Dive Deep,
they usually think it has to
be related to a technical skill.
But actually no.
For example, say you are
discussing a demand with a client.
And you want to make this
demand as specific as possible.

Then you run into many difficulties
while discussing this demand,

such as, for example,
the client doesn’t cooperate,
their words are too vague,

or you want to discuss
it with your colleagues, but they
are not familiar with this area,

or they are too busy to
spare some time for you, etc.
These things can also be

used as examples
for an interview. They don’t
need to be related to skills.
You can also note this down.
The next one is Task.
What Task means is,
let’s use a previous example,
say our SQL is too slow.
What do you want to do about it?
What is the Task you want to do?
What is your goal?
The first one is to speed it up.

How long does it
take originally?
Say 10 seconds.
So my goal would probably be
to make it 5 seconds,
or perhaps 3 seconds.
And next one,

for the third one “Action”,
you will follow this goal.
Ok, in order to

make SQL faster, is it
enough to just add an Index?
But there are various Indexes.

You also need to see whether
adding an index will affect
other applications.

These are the things you must
describe in good details.
So for this part,

many people would just say:
SQL Query is too slow.
I added an Index to make it fast.

That’s all.
But actually,
you can make it more interesting.
For example, you’ll definitely do
some analysis for adding an Index,
because you can’t make any random
change in a production environment.
Who did you communicate with

before implementing this?
It’s definitely the user.
Who knows about the data the most?

Maybe there is another engineer.
And other related matters.
These are all details that
you can talk about for Action.
And for this purpose, you should
avoid saying “we or us”.
You should focus on yourself.
Because interviewers want to

know what you have done for
this task.
What is your contribution?

If you mostly use “we”
in your description,

the interviewers would
feel curious and probably
want to ask more questions to

figure out
what role you

played in
this troubleshooting task
that you were handling.
Actually as long as you clearly
specify your duties in this task,
it can save them a lot of efforts.

This is something you can
keep in mind.
The last one is Result.
What Result did you get?
Like after you added the Index,
the SQL is 50% faster,
or 10% faster than

the original, etc.
You also did some optimizations.
So this is a good Result.

It allows the interviewers
to fully understand

what you have done
in the troubleshooting

task for this
SQL Query, and how
you responded to the issue.

They can then see your
communication skills, and

figure out your
technical depth, etc.
Even with the simplest example,
we can still obtain many data

points from the process
of your explaining words.

Everything you say will be
critical and will greatly

help the interviewers
reach a decision.

So this is the STAR
interview tips that
we highly recommend.
And then
it’s the interview process.

We review the resume.
We assess the technical skills.

Then we look at what you have
done before, and here you can
apply the tips we just mentioned.
These are the domains that
we need right now.
But you might not see

all of the vacancies related to
these domains on
our Amazon Job website.
But you can check back regularly.
And
we post new vacancies
from time to time.
For the “How to Apply” section,

you can take photos of
the information first, or

we will give you relevant
information after the webinar.

Then you can reach out
via the website or contact the
corresponding colleagues.

I want to add something
about the English proficiency.
As a foreign company, we expect you

to have basic English proficiency.
But you don’t need to worry.

We don’t expect you to talk
like a native English speaker.
But we want you to be able to

at least understand English, and
can express yourself in English.

Because you will have a lot of
colleagues from other countries.

As long as you can communicate
in English, it is

actually beneficial to your
career growth.
Ok, so this is
some interview tips that
I want to share with you.

Now I will hand
it over to Mark.
Mark will share some

of his ideas about
AWS Networking.
